Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I stared at my phone, reading the group chat messages from my siblings. They were excitedly planning our annual family trip, set for the same weekend as Diwali. As the eldest, I was expected to join, help organize, and be present for every moment—my parents always said family comes first. But as a practicing Hindu, Diwali is sacred to me. I had already promised to help decorate the temple, prepare sweets, and attend the evening puja in traditional attire. My heart twisted as I imagined missing the laughter and stories with my siblings, but the thought of skipping the Diwali ceremony filled me with guilt and unease. Both sides expected my full presence, and I felt torn in two, unable to meet the demands of both my family and my faith. I sat in silence, wrestling with the impossible choice, feeling the weight of disappointing someone no matter what I decided.
